awd_titl_txt: RR:  EAGER Collaborative Research:  Building Dynamic Research Communities in Global Legal Studies
awd_abstract_narration:
Comparative and international legal approaches provide the foundation for future scientific innovation. Complex legal frameworks are increasingly offered as the solution to the most pressing issues of our time.  The issues transcend borders, levels of governance, and areas of policy expertise demanding coordination, collaboration, and convergence to create sustainable institutional solutions to these pressing societal needs.

This project pilots a new model for collaborative and convergent research communities in law and social sciences. The project aims to form the critical connections, commitments, and institutionalization to ensure a transformative change in how research on comparative and international law is designed and implemented, and how the findings and data from the research are disseminated.  To date, lack of transparency, limited accountability, poorly-sustained graduate mentorship, and an absence of a commonly-accepted platform for data sharing have led to a fragmented field and a large number of single-use data projects. In turn, this has hampered the ability to sustain research agendas resolving salient legal questions.  The project develops three collaborative components: data infrastructure, Idea Labs, and an Annual Research Workshop. Together, these institutional innovations will ensure the reproducibility, replicability, and generalizability of data in the field of law and social sciences, and they will create a new multidisciplinary and interdisciplinary collaborative team model that is better equipped to embrace the complexity and scope of global legal challenges.

por.por_cntn:
This grant was intended to facilitate multiple venues for collaboration among researchers across the globe, helping support travel and collaboration that otherwise might be funded through other means ? either through researcher?s own institutional funds or through grant proposals. The desire to support collaboration was designed especially to benefit an international community of scholars, not just those from the United States, but also scholars from Europe, Asia, Latin America, and Africa. At the start of this grant, we proposed three activities to achieve this goal: a data infrastructure component, periodic in-person workshops called Idea Labs, and an Annual Research Workshop.

In light of the ongoing pandemic, we pivoted our planned meetings and research collaborations to online formats. This shift has become a serendipitous opportunity, leading to successful collaborations among scholars throughout the world. This year, we have built upon the virtual platform adopted in early 2020, expanding the accessibility of our workshops to a larger network of scholars. The adoption of virtual platforms has helped us host three ongoing programs, a global workshop in collaboration with the Centre on Law and Social Transformation at the University of Bergen, a monthly workshop for scholars, and a bi-monthly workshop series for graduate students and early-career scholars.

In the last originally-scheduled year of this grant we hosted a two-day virtual meeting of global law and politics researchers in in collaboration with the Centre on Law and Social Transformation (itself a collaboration between the University of Bergen and the Christian Michelsen Institute, Bergen, Norway). We had presenters from Europe and the US, who presented research on the US, Africa, Latin America, and Western, Central and Eastern Europe.

 Continuing that collaboration, over the past two years, we continued a virtual global meeting for scholars. We organized Workshop Wednesdays, a workshop series on the first Wednesday of each month, at which we workshop one paper. We held 8 meetings in 2021 and have already scheduled 5 more, through May of 2022. Attendance at each of these meetings has been around 30 people. We had more requests than we could accommodate this year and the list of people who have indicated interest in presenting or attending currently stands at 199.

         Furthermore, we also have supported scholarship by early-career researchers. Using some of our funding, we have supported the creation of the Junior Law and Politics Research Community, a collaboration among graduate students to host workshops for graduate students, post-doctorate fellows, and early-career faculty. These workshops take place twice a month. The first Wednesday of each month features two informal ?bullet talks,? informal presentations featuring early-stage ideas for research projects or smaller aspects of ongoing projects. The final Wednesday of each month workshops one paper, with a faculty discussant. Attendance at these meetings is around 20-25 people. For these meetings also, we have more requests to present than we can accommodate. Meetings have already been scheduled through December 2021, with plans to continue these workshops through June 2022.

Our experiences from the past year have created a foundation to expand this network to support more opportunities over online fora. The success of our Workshop Wednesdays and the Junior Law and Politics Research Community demonstrate that researchers at all stages of their careers have found the virtual model both useful and accessible. The online model has expanded our capacity to facilitate scholarly exchange beyond the in-person formats initially planned by our team. While we believe some in-person meetings will be necessary to maintain momentum in the future, our experiences from this past year demonstrate both an appetite for the online model and the potential for future success of these approach.


Last Modified: 12/30/2021
Modified by: Daniel M Brinks
